title: 105_s620
content: The "Women's Investment and Savings Equity Act of 1997" allows individuals to make deductible IRA contributions without considering their spouse's participation in a pension plan. Additionally, individuals are permitted to make contributions during periods of maternity or paternity leave. The amendment allows individuals to make contributions during maternity and paternity leave, affecting the qualification of trusts and plans under various sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under a deferred compensation plan under section 457. This provision ensures that contributions during leave are treated appropriately under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under a deferred compensation plan under section 457 without being subject to certain contribution limitations. The amendment allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under a deferred compensation plan under section 457 without being subject to certain contribution limitations. Contributions under the plan shall be subject to specific limitations for the relevant year, and the plan must meet certain requirements to avoid noncompliance. The amendment allows additional elective deferrals under a deferred compensation plan without certain contribution limitations. Matching contributions are not required for these deferrals, but if made, must meet specific requirements. The amendment allows additional elective deferrals under a deferred compensation plan without contribution limitations. Matching contributions, if made, must meet specific requirements such as separate application to all contributions and not exceeding the maximum amount allowed under the plan. The plan must meet specific requirements for elective deferrals during eligible maternity and paternity leave, ensuring they do not exceed the maximum allowed amount under the plan. Proper adjustment shall be made to the amount determined for elective deferrals made during the 3-year period following eligible maternity and paternity leave, with compensation determined under similar rules. During the 3-year period after eligible maternity or paternity leave, matching contributions for elective deferrals must be made by the employer's tax return due date. Eligible leave refers to an individual's absence from work for any period. During eligible maternity or paternity leave, an individual can be absent from work for reasons related to pregnancy, childbirth, adoption, or caring for a child. The maximum leave period is 12 weeks. During eligible maternity or paternity leave, an individual can be absent from work for reasons related to pregnancy, childbirth, adoption, or caring for a child, with a maximum leave period of 12 months for any child. Definitions and rules include elective deferral, plan arrangements under section 408 (k) or (p), and certain retroactive adjustments. Effective December 31, 1997, rules regarding loan repayment suspensions during eligible maternity and paternity leave will apply, with certain retroactive adjustments not required. SEC. 4. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Catchup Contributions for Families With Children Not Covered by a Pension Plan: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to specify that certain plans will not be considered qualified trusts under section 401(a), described in section 403(b), or eligible deferred compensation plans under section 457. The text discusses the requirements for a deferred compensation plan under section 457, stating that an arrangement must allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals in order to meet certain requirements. Additionally, it mentions that a plan should permit eligible participants to make catchup contributions in certified catchup years. The plan must limit additional elective deferrals to the lesser of the participant's usual deferral amount for the year or a specified limit. The plan limits elective deferrals to 120 percent of the applicable dollar limitation for the year, minus any other elective deferrals made by the participant. The contribution to a plan under paragraph (1) is not subject to any applicable limitation for the year it is made. Employer matching contributions are also included in this treatment. The contribution to a plan under paragraph (1) is not subject to any applicable limitation for the year it is made, including sections 402(g), 402(h), 403(b), 404(a), 404(h), 408, 415, or 457. Contributions or benefits under the plan shall not cause it to fail to meet section requirements. The contribution to a plan under paragraph (1) is not subject to any applicable limitation for the year it is made, including various sections. Failing to meet certain requirements due to contributions is addressed, with exceptions for matching contributions. Matching contributions made to a plan are subject to separate application of section 401(a)(4) requirements. The amount of matching contributions cannot exceed the maximum allowed under the plan for elective deferrals without this subsection. Participants must certify catchup years for making contributions. Participants making additional elective deferrals must certify eligibility and catchup years to the plan administrator. An eligible participant can certify one or more catchup years, not exceeding a total specified limit. The number of certified years cannot exceed the limit specified in paragraph (3) before the current year, minus the years previously certified by the participant. Plans are not held responsible for certification failures. Plans are not responsible for certification failures unless the administrator knew or should have known about the incorrect certification. Eligible participants are defined as plan participants in previous calendar years. In previous calendar years, eligible participants are those who were not active participants for any plan year and had a child under 18 for whom a deduction was allowed. The term 'elective deferral' includes after-tax employee contributions. 'Plan' encompasses arrangements under section 408 (k) or (p). Certain retroactive adjustments are not required for this subchapter and subchapter E. The amendment's effective date is specified. The amendment made by this section shall apply to contributions in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
